content.body: I'm writing up the PR now, and I'm suddenly struck by an idea: instead of `when` as the branch introducer, should we use `is`? That makes it perfectly match up with the boolean form, just with an implicit LHS coming from the match block itself.
content.formatted_body: I'm writing up the PR now, and I'm suddenly struck by an idea: instead of when as the branch introducer, should we use is? That makes it perfectly match up with the boolean form, just with an implicit LHS coming from the match block itself.

that is:

match(foo) {
  is [let a]: ...;
  is {bar}: ...;
  default: ...;
}

content.body: which syncs up with saying `foo is [let a]` outside of the match construct
content.formatted_body: which syncs up with saying foo is [let a] outside of the match construct

content.body: that's not bad, but there's a distinct difference wrt bindings
also "is" and "default" don't pair very well imo
